misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based indexing / “arrays count like humans” mental model
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes array positions start at 1 (the “first element is at position 1”) and that the last valid position is arraySize, so loops should run from 1 through arraySize inclusive.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, array indexing is 0-based: the first element is at index 0 and the last element is at index arraySize - 1. Any attempt to access userInputArray[arraySize] is out of bounds. Loops that go 1..arraySize will skip index 0 and also attempt to write/read index arraySize, causing a runtime exception.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException during input, shifting, and/or printing.

evidence.code_snippet: int currentIndex = 1; // I will start from 1 because I want to count all elements in a human way
while (currentIndex <= arraySize) {
userInputArray[currentIndex] = userInputValue; // I think index currentIndex should match the element number
int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySize];
int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize
userInputArray[1] = lastElementTemporaryHolder;
int printIndex = 1; // Start from 1 because I think the first element is at position 1
while (printIndex <= arraySize) {
int valueToPrintTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[printIndex];

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: “Array size equals last index” confusion (size vs. highest valid index)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the variable arraySize directly names a valid position in the array (i.e., if size is 4, index 4 exists and is the last slot).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, array.length is the count of elements, not the last index. The last index is length - 1. Treating length as an index causes out-of-bounds access even if they otherwise intended a right shift algorithm.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, specifically when accessing index arraySize.

evidence.code_snippet: int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySize];
int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize
while (currentIndex <= arraySize) {
while (printIndex <= arraySize) {

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices should start at 1 to match human counting conventions ("element 1", "element 2", etc.), rather than starting at 0 as Java requires. The student thinks that index 1 is the 'first position' and index arraySize is the 'last position'.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. Valid indices range from 0 to arraySize-1. The student is using indices 1 to arraySize, which means: (1) element at index 0 is never initialized and remains 0, (2) accessing userInputArray[arraySize] causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, and (3) the logic treats index positions inconsistently with Java's actual memory model.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when accessing userInputArray[arraySize], or if that doesn't crash, incorrect/missing values in the output because index 0 was skipped and contains a default 0 value.

evidence.code_snippet: int currentIndex = 1; // I will start from 1 because I want to count all elements in a human way

int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize
userInputArray[1] = lastElementTemporaryHolder;
int printIndex = 1; // Start from 1 because I think the first element is at position 1

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices correspond directly to human counting, where the first element is at index 1 and the final element is located at an index equal to the size of the array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed, meaning the first element is at index 0 and the last valid index is 'length - 1'. The student's model assumes indices range from 1 to 'length', leading to an out-of-bounds access and an unused memory slot at index 0.

userInputArray[1] = lastElementTemporaryHolder;

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based array indexing / “array positions match human counting”
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed starting at 1 (so the “first element” is at index 1) and that the “last position” is at index arraySize. They treat array indices like human element numbers: 1st, 2nd, …, Nth.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: for an array of length N, the valid indices are 0 through N-1. Index N (i.e., arraySize) is *outside* the array. Because of this, using indices 1..arraySize will skip index 0 and attempt to access index arraySize, which triggers an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. The machine does not map “element number” to “array index” automatically; the programmer must translate between 1-based human counting and 0-based indexing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) during input, shifting, and/or printing; also logically incorrect shift because index 0 is never used.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices work like human counting, where the first element is at position 1, the second at position 2, and so on. They think the 'last position' of an array of size N is at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays use 0-based indexing: valid indices range from 0 to arraySize-1. The last element is at index arraySize-1, not arraySize. The student's mental model treats arrays as if they were numbered like a human list (1, 2, 3, ..., N) rather than as a zero-indexed data structure (0, 1, 2, ..., N-1).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime. The code attempts to read a 5th element into an array of size 4 (line 30: userInputArray[currentIndex] when currentIndex=4), and also attempts to access userInputArray[arraySize] which is out of bounds (line 37).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices are 1-based, matching human counting (1 to N), rather than 0-based (0 to N-1). They assume the first element of an array is at index 1 and the last element is at index equal to the array's size.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use zero-based indexing. An array of length 'N' has valid indices from 0 to N-1. Attempting to access an index equal to the array length results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, and the element at index 0 is left unused/ignored.
